w:r.w:t: If you have a demo, what's the url? For non-software, demo can be a video.
(Please don't password protect it; just use an obscure url.)
Sandpit / pre populated Savvy where they can see the integrations we use, ask Savvy questions e.g. Bug progress, get a file, get an illustration, get a text snippet, verification etc.
Describe your company in 50 characters or less.
Spotlight search meets Zapier
What is your company going to make?
Savvy in an online tool that allows a user to search and update any piece of content in any web based application via a Slack Bot, browser extension and web app.
It does this by acting as a universal API, even for services that don’t have APIs (by scraping and indexing). To a user it’s a way of accessing your various pieces of content, all without
being locked
behind another login or having to open another app or tab.

We’re not focussed on searching files across apps (that’s been tried many a time) but rather focussed on extracting an exact answer from somewhere within multiple silos of information. It doesn’t matter what sort of content it is (docs, data, Trello cards, Github issues, images etc.), Savvy unifies and makes the content within those apps searchable,
all the way down to the actual answer, not just the file.

A typical organisation’s information is spread across dozens of cloud services, and the vast majority of touchpoints with these tools are for simple read/write operations. There is no reason why users should need to waste time loading and switching between tools just to refer to or update information.

They shouldn’t even need to care which service/folder/file/page a document, customer profile or issue lives. If they want to update a feature request, they should just search and see a feature request card, simple as that.

The ultimate goal is a Google Assistant style approach that ‘coaches’ you on how best to do your job based not only on your workflows/ habits but on the collective learnings of the company (through similar roles) and potentially across industry.
Comment:
Please enter the url of a 1 minute unlisted (not private) YouTube video introducing the founders.
!TO DO! - we’ll record this on Friday
Please tell us about an interesting project, preferably outside of class or work, that two or more of you created together. Include urls if possible.
We built a voter advice tool (read: quiz)
for the General Election 2017
over the course of a few days and scaled it to over 2.2 million unique people completing it in just 4 weeks. We completely
redesigned
what ‘election quizzes’ meant, and doubled the previous national record for a voter advice tool, despite having
a team of 3
and using zero ad spend.
The average user spent 12 minutes on the site, 91% of all users who started it completed it and 1 in 6 shared the site URL. This is now an open source project . A
group of Italian volunteers forking the technology for this year’s Italian election.
www.ge2017.com
(UK tool)
www.elezioni18.it/quiz
(Italian tool)
How long have the founders known one another and how did you meet? Have any of the founders not met in person?

We met via Twitter in early 2016 after building rival products in a similar space. Jeremy was a superior coder and had better product sense. Matt was better at marketing and distribution, had previously built a team and raised money. We’ve been working together in person for approximately 14 months.

During those 14 months we’ve been obsessed with making knowledge accessible where you need it and went through what we call ‘hell month’ where we worked together for 18 hours a day 7 days a week to get our election project running. We’ve disagreed on multiple occasions but have found frameworks that work for us to resolve our disagreements in a fair but prompt manner.
How far along are you?

We originally came up with an idea of what Savvy would be in December 2016 as an internal tool. We developed a click through prototype (purely front end) which allowed us to attract 30 business sign ups with letters of intent in Jan/Feb 2018. Since then we’ve had more than 150 individual customer conversations with mid size businesses (around 500 employees or less) and built a product plan for the next 6 months.
We’ve also launched a marketing site (
www.heysavvy.com

) and have a ‘Preview Release’ field that allows us to capture leads. Savvy is now in use internally and has a web app, Slack bot and browser extension fully functional. In addition we have built our own custom integration framework, scraping and parsing algorithms and our own ‘trust’ score to assign to content as it’s surfaced.

Over the past 6 weeks we have accumulated a waiting list of 150 companies ranging from Financial Times to Crowdcube. We add between 3-5 companies a week to this preview release list. As of 20th March we’re shipping to our first company on a 14-Day free trial basis. As a result we expect to be revenue generating by mid April and reach 500 weekly active users by late April.
How long have each of you been working on this? Have you been part-time or full-time? Please explain.
We’ve been working on Savvy in its current form for roughly 4 months. We’re both full time with this our sole focus. Irrespective of being invited to join YC, we are continuing with Savvy.
How many active users or customers do you have? If you have some particularly valuable customers, who are they?
We’re not currently live as of time of writing. We have over 150 businesses signed up for Preview Release (since January) and among those companies are Financial Times, Crowdcube, CAT and Coca Cola.

We’ve had one major set back recently with Monzo dropping from our list, opting to build their own version rather than buying for us. They state that this is due to them wanting custom solutions to keep up with their rate of growth.
Anything else you would like us to know regarding your revenue or growth rate?
We’re growing our Preview Release list by 15 % a week. We’re deploying to 3 companies a week with 100 users currently live.
If you have already participated or committed to participate in an incubator, "accelerator" or "pre-accelerator" program, please tell us about it.

The Geovation accelerator (which focuses on startups using geodata) contacted us after our ge2017.com success (which did use geodata) and made it clear that they were willing to accept Savvy based on backing the team, even if geodata never became a strong part of the product. They had a light-touch/hands-off approach and didn’t take equity so we accepted, and certainly don’t regret the decision. We gained access to customer contacts, free office space and £30,000. However we would definitely benefit from a more focussed, hands-on accelerator at this stage that specialises n fast growth potential tech startups.
Why did you pick this idea to work on? Do you have domain expertise in this area? How do you know people need what you're making?

We experienced it ourselves during the scaling of our election product. It just seemed stupid that we had all these apps with information spread across them that we couldn’t easily access, let alone trust as we scaled and new knowledge was created everyday. So we built a clickable prototype and showed it to our network and they began to give feedback and place pre-orders.

We view this within a stronger trend that the internet is repeating itself with the majority of the market obsessed with creating new silos of information behind logins and app ‘walls’. This will result in a discovery problem again, much like the 1990’s for the consumer web. On top of that as more services are offered and adopted, the shift will transfer from search to ‘trust’ meaning knowing if you can act on what you find will be as critical to a business as finding it.
We’re not focussed on searching files across apps (that’s been tried many a time) but rather focussed on extracting an exact answer from a silo of information.

Our experience with journalism, speechwriting and building election tools has always revolved around solving problems of information overload and silos: taking the vast expanse of long, poorly organised, hard to find information and making sure our users never have to worry about it, yet have full control and transparency when they need it.
What's new about what you're making? What substitutes do people resort to because it doesn't exist yet (or they don't know about it)?

The majority don't realise it yet, but it's totally unnecessary and hugely time-intensive to go through the process of digging out the correct cloud service, document, page and line. Then put in the work to verify its accuracy, just to get the answer they need. We know for a fact that it's perfectly feasible to give them an Instant Answer, in the place where they're currently working, with transparent, at-a-glance info on who/where/when it came from so they know they can trust it.

We’re focussing on the core need for teams to have accurate, up to date information they can trust where they’re working so they can do their job. Most people have each application they need open in a new tab and deal with each interface separately. When they don’t know the answer or can’t find what they need, they send a Slack message / email or go and find the person to ask.
Most teams leverage some form of collective drive and then use different tools according to their job.
According to

Forrester, a typical 150 person B2B SaaS company uses 28 separate cloud apps. Currently teams find what they’re looking for using enterprise search, the search bar in each native app or just asking someone which is typically the default. Our real ‘battle’ is against the latter by offering a search bar that is Google esque in its ability to deliver accurate answers but adaptive enough to live where that person is working.

The problem is also growing not only due to the proliferation of work apps but by the shift from search to discovery. Using keyword search is a 20th century answer as it’ll just return all results matching key terms with no broader context on usage, trust score or credibility of that information in front of them. What people want is the exact answer where they’re working and secure in the knowledge that when they act on said information it’s right.

Unlike general-purpose search, we can dramatically improve search results purely because we have a good idea of the sorts of things people will be searching for. A simple example: from the word “who” in a search query we can prioritise a result that’s a row of a spreadsheet that looks like a CRM.
Getting this right for one company will mean the search works even better out of the box for the next company.
Who are your competitors, and who might become competitors? Who do you fear most?
Direct competitors:
Always want to either a. Serve you a file or b. Get you to re-write your content into their format
Guru - does a good job providing knowledge where you work (Slack, browser and web app) but requires you to rewrite everything into their format,

which is a HUGE investment for a new customer to make. When we’ve carried out interviews with customers they cite the bloated feature list of Guru, its’ confusing UI and the need to rewrite content as a main reason they prefer our offering.

Butter.AI let’s you search for files from Slack (soon to be in Chrome too) but again only offers a whole file return. When files were the dominant format (say 5 years ago) this would have been fine. However consumer trends, which inform business trends, have now lead to the expectation that we get an answer instantly through a chat like interface. We fear someone like Butter the most as their UX/UI is solid, have an experienced team and are well funded. They seem more focussed on solving multiple problems for teams (with knowledge sharing being the first), haven’t released any major updates in months, given no indication of traction and aren’t focussing on connecting work apps together just surfacing files.

New tab - this is the ‘status quo’ and the current solution in place. Most people just leave open tabs and hop between them as and when they need the information. Along with our own experience and speaking to users, tools that condense open tabs are on the rise which we view as a sign that this current method isn’t
working.

We launched Savvy Time as a tool that allowed a user to see how much time they spent switching tabs and working on work apps. Whilst the uptake was poor we felt it was worth an experiment to see how this ‘New tab’ phenomenon could be explored.
Indirect competitors:
Google Drive search is okay but
only returns files which you then have to open, is
misunderstood by most people as they think it only
searches
file
titles (meaning they’re confused as they can’t see why they got certain search results)
and obviously only works for Google Drive.
In

app search. Most modern work apps have a reasonably good search interface but the issue of trust and context are lacking. They’re also siloed away and all function differently (and change frequently) so are hard to rely on.
Dropbox could further expand its collaboration efforts and aim to extract answers from information silos but again they’d probably start with their own service and work from there.
What do you understand about your business that other companies in it just don't get?
Competing products work at the wrong layer of abstraction and/or force the user to
constantly

think about how and where they’ve stored their knowledge. As the number of apps used by teams continues to grow, remote teams become the new norm and time to response (both externally and internally) drops, the need for both search and discovery for trusted information is vital. We come at it from trying to give you a snippet of an answer whether that be a card with a specific answer or a file.

Most established players can’t compete without connecting to competitors’ systems and new entrants need training data which is harder to come by in the B2B space. Savvy meets the end user’s expectation that work applications should feel and work like the ones they use at home. They click a button, type a question and get an answer and expect software to do the heavy lifting. Soon we’ll be able to preempt what they need based on task, URL or previous usage which will open a new paradigm of proactive content.
How do or will you make money? How much could you make?
(We realize you can't know precisely, but give your best estimate.)

We’re currently operating on a free trial model with all features included in a 14-Day trial with a tiered pricing model kicking in when it expires. We bill according to features used by the end user. A searchable wiki that lives where you work in
per month/ per user scaling to £45 per month per user for verification, analytics and custom integrations. A typical mid size internet based company is worth roughly £2000 + VAT to Savvy per month.

We have a broad net of customers and are still identifying the ideal customer profile but we believe that our revenue could hit the hundreds of millions based on the explosion of work apps (we foresee a 25x increase in number of SaaS products entering the market within the next 5-7 years) and the need to access content spread across them all.

How will you get users? If your idea is the type that faces a chicken-and-egg problem in the sense that it won't be attractive to users till it has a lot of users (e.g. a marketplace, a dating site, an ad network), how will you overcome that?

We operate a direct to seller model using an inside sales team. We typically identify customers according to the integrations they use and the team size they’re in. For example a 50 person tech startup who use Jira, Slack and Confluence are an ideal candidate for Savvy. We are also in a position where Savvy can be used by the majority of roles within a company, especially those who are customer facing. As a result we have multiple ‘in roads’ to close that deal. So far we’ve found an equal split between teams signing up to use Savvy for customer support and sales.
Currently our average deal size does not allow for a field sales team but if the average account value increases and corporates begin to bite, then we will shift.
Please describe the breakdown of the equity ownership in percentages among the founders, employees and any other stockholders.
Matthew Morley - 50% - Class A Shares. Jeremy Evans - 50% - Class A Shares. That’s it.
Are any of the founders covered by noncompetes or intellectual property agreements that overlap with your project? If so, please explain.
Who writes code, or does other technical work on your product? Was any of it done by a non-founder? Please explain.
Jeremy: 80% (parsing, scraping, indexing, integrations, read/write APIs, Slack Bot)
Matt: 20% (marketing site, NLP training and occasional Python debug)

If you had any other ideas you considered applying with, please list them. One may be something we've been waiting for. Often when we fund people it's to do something they list here and not in the main application.

Explaain - interactive fact cards that overlap additional content on any article (or any form of static content) so you don’t have to open a new tab to understand something. E.g. Article on GDPR, you click on GDPR and it’ll explain what that is without the author having to elongate the article. We tried this before Savvy but with a lack of money in the journalism space, this wasn’t financially viable.
Please tell us something surprising or amusing that one of you has discovered.
(The answer need not be related to your project.)

When we were building our election site our first version was optimised for speed as we felt that busy people on smartphones on the way to the polling station wanted an answer quickly. What that resulted in was a near instant answer when a user hit ‘Show me my results’. Traction was terrible, maybe 200 or 300 people used it. We decided as an experiment, to add a delay of 300 m/s and adding a spinner that artificially delayed the user after going on a price comparison website and seeing one there. The results were staggering. Usage was nearly instantly higher and all key metrics including number of completes, number of shares and time on site rocketed be something like 500%. Moral of the story?
You can only earn trust from users by giving them transparency AND great design.
What convinced you to apply to Y Combinator?

While we’re incredibly self motivating and driven to deliver an awesome experience for customers, we definitely feel that we move the needle most when someone is relentlessly picking us apart (read: bollocking us). So if we can get a solid three months of that then it can only be a good thing.
In exchange for joining the program we hope we’re offering a unique background and eagerness to learn from the community.
YC spiel
Maths behind YC
Things that set us apart
